required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of a Smoke-Free Homes Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial to Test the Efficacy of a Smoke-Free Homes Intervention in Promoting Cessation.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test whether the integration of a smoke-free homes intervention into the clinical guidelines for tobacco cessation can encourage sustained smoking cessation in low-income primary care patients.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test whether the integration of a smoke-free homes intervention into the clinical guidelines for tobacco cessation can encourage sustained smoking cessation in low-income primary care patients. The intervention consists of five components, three interactive mailings and two coaching calls, focused on creating home and vehicle(s) smoking bans among smokers.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants who achieved smoking cessation/abstinence

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants self-reported 30-day abstinence at six-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of patients self-reported 30-day abstinence at six-month follow-up will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants self-reported 30-day abstinence at 12-month follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of patients self-reported 30-day abstinence at 12-month follow-up will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in number of cigarettes smoked per day on smoking days
secondary_outcome.description: Number of cigarettes smoked per day on smoking days will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of quit attempts at 6-month follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of quit attempts will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of quit attempts at 12-month follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Number of quit attempts will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants that established smoke-free home and vehicle rules
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants that established smoke-free home and vehicle rules will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in number of cigarettes smoked in the home
secondary_outcome.description: Number of cigarettes smoked in the home will be recorded

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of abstinence (i.e. days since last use) at 6-month follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of abstinence (i.e. days since last use) will be self-reported

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of abstinence (i.e. days since last use) at 12-month follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of abstinence (i.e. days since last use) will be self-reported

arm_group.description: Participants in the intervention condition will receive the expanded Smoke-Free Homes intervention. Follow-up will be at six and twelve months, including saliva cotinine validation for reported 7-day cessation.

The usual care/control arm will receive mailed information on the QL (quitline), and a connection to the QL at their request. Follow-up will be at six and twelve months, including saliva cotinine validation for reported 7-day cessation.

intervention.description: The adapted smoke-free homes intervention consists of five components, three interactive mailings and two coaching calls, focused on creating home and vehicle(s) smoking bans among smokers. The intervention is based on principles of Social Cognitive Theory and the Transtheoretical Model's stages of change. The rationale underlying the intervention is that creation of additional smoke-free environments will reduce situational and environmental cues to smoke, reduce opportunities and places to smoke, increase self-efficacy for quitting and increase motivation to quit. The intervention uses persuasion, role modeling, behavioral contracting and goal setting to move smokers through behavioral capability, outcome expectations and self-efficacy for strict smoke-free rules, creation of and compliance/enforcement with smoke-free rules, reduced cigarettes smoked per day, increased motivation to quit, increased quit attempts, and successful cessation.

The usual care/control arm will receive mailed information on the QL (quitline - free cessation counseling offered to all Georgia residents by the state of Georgia), and a connection to the QL at their request. Follow-up will be at six and twelve months, including saliva cotinine validation for reported 7-day cessation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age and older
- referred by primary care physician or provider of a participating FQHC in South Georgia
- having smoked at least one cigarette in the past 30 days
- has ability to speak and understand English
- be the only patient per household to be enrolled in the study
- not currently be enrolled in a cessation program
Exclusion Criteria:
- non-smoker
- unable to speak or understand English
- under 18 years of age
- pregnant women
- prisoners
- cognitively impaired or Individuals with Impaired Decision-Making Capacity
- not able to clearly understand English
- community participation
- having another family or household member participating in the research

facility.name: Rollins School of Public Health, Emory University

patient_data.ipd_description: Data from the quantitative surveys at baseline and follow-up (6 and 12 month) will be shared
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Access will be granted to investigators who submit a request to the PI for any analyses that are not planned by the research team (with a description of the research question, desired variables, analysis plan, and dissemination plan).
